What I absolutely hate is when I am alone in a squad game, matchmaking is often so broken. Also, input lag and network lag are so bad, you need to fix this before I can give a positive review. Apart from that, I love the game.

Apparently, you need to go to the settings. It's set by default on "Borderless" which ruins the gameplay. Setting it on Fullscreen, no more keyboard input lag. Crazy stupid how this is a general problem yet it's a default setting.

For me, game is fun cause it feels realistic. Achievements are really time consuming but I wanna do them. Game is still alive, though there are many bots (at least in casual). Not an issue for me, since I'm not good & they make it easier.

I've only played classic and random so far. I more often see level 300+ players than around mine (60). Sometimes it's annoying when I clearly get owned by someone much more experienced, but I'm still in the learning phase so I'm still enjoying the game.

I will try to be as objective as possible.
I have never had so mixed feeling about any game. This game is different. I have never played so much addicting game but at the same time so ruined by devs decision.

PROS:
- gunplay - honestly the best gunplay ever made
- drive bys - probably the funniest element ever created in games (requires a lot of practice)
- adrenaline - never ending top 10 adrenaline
- every game is unique
- that headshot feeling (Imagine "feels good meme" here)
- guns balance

CONS:
- somebody delusional from company management gives makes decisions
- I am really disappointed about that this game does not appreciate active plays. I consider myself as aggressive player and this really frustrates me, because no matter if you play public or ranked you are always rewarded better for playing passive than active. That means if you finish in top 10 with 1 kill you get rewarded better than ending 25th with 10kills.
- devs really don´t listen to feedback. Even if they say they do, they really don´t. No debate.
- devs prioritizion money over quality. If they produce bug fixing and quality improvements with same speed as they produce skins we would be playing elsewhere today (not losing players linearly).
- addition of bots - I believe this step killed the game for A LOT of players - worst step ever made.
- devs do not play the game. This is really interesting point because when you look at some changes they really makes no sense



- lot of people complain about cheaters but I can´t say I meet them a lot lately.

People say this game is dead but I do not agree. Daily peak is less than 500k players per day. So it´s still good.

Somewhere, buried very, very. very deep, beneath a mountain of incompetence, poor design choices, a buggy engine and a boatload of hackers, there lurks a fun game.  It can be found occasionally, curled up, crying in the shower, while the developers are around the corner, combining their collective (5) brain cells - trying to reinvigorate this trainwreck, and invariably, making it worse.

This could have been THE battle royale game.  instead, it's just another shitty battle royale game.

Playing PUBG: Battlegrounds has been quite an experience. The game’s realistic simulation and massive zones make it stand out among other battle royales. The thrill of survival after parachuting into the open world is unmatched. The need to be stealthy and tactical adds a layer of complexity that I appreciate. Waiting for a passing aircraft to drown out my footsteps or using a smokescreen to distract enemies are just some of the strategies I’ve used.

However, the game isn’t without its flaws. The wide selection of guns can be clunky to fire, especially compared to other modern shooters. The weapons are more tolerable in third-person mode, but they’re frustratingly inaccurate unless you switch to first-person or aim down sights. This can be a bit of a letdown, especially when you’re in the heat of a firefight.

Despite these issues, I still find myself coming back to PUBG: Battlegrounds. The game’s emphasis on realistic bullet physics sets it apart in an interesting way. It’s not as slick as some other games, but the intensity of the fights keeps me engaged. The game has managed to stay relevant and enjoyable with continuous updates and a player-focused approach. It’s a compelling choice for anyone seeking a challenging and realistic battle royale experience. All in all, I’d say PUBG: Battlegrounds is worth a shot.

[2018 Review]
Not sure why most of the reviews on this is negative. I'm having a good time.

(Note: Lag is easily what causes 99% of every death I've had thus far.)

[2021 Review]
Lag and packet loss is terrible and you can't pick a better server since the game automatically decides 'best' server. Connection issues frequently plague the game worse than in its hey day.

Duo FPP servers are mostly bots, very low player counts in this mode.

Game crashes every other launch, devs and company don't seem to care to resolve the issue.

$10+ outfits proudly for sale. Way too expensive for an in-game cosmetic item.

'Loot boxes' (or what I consider to be basically loot boxes) only contain randomized items that can be bought for real money. BP seems to have no reason for existing. Contraband tokens seem to have no use either. (Okay well, I finally managed to find a way to use BP so... I can correct this point)

The gameplay is still as fun as I remember it, but there's more negatives now than before. I love how things sound and how the guns feel... 

It's a sad state of affairs, but I can see why many people moved on to other games...

[2024 Review]

I keep coming back to this game because the guns feel so good. Though many of the issues mentioned above are still a concern, I think the game is pretty good right now. I haven't seen many cheaters in recent matches and the matches feel relatively evenly matched for me (aka not many players who are just way better than me in the average match). Give it a try!

So several years ago, I decided I wanted to play this game and payed 30 dollars for it like a fucking moron. I found this game extremely boring, but with 7 hours of gameplay to my name, there was no hope steam would refund me. Needless to say this has sat in my library since then. In between now and the time I originally bought this game, it has gone from just a simply sweaty and toxic community, to an all out hacker battlefield. Where you don't face players with 20,000 hours, you are facing waves of hackers. It's amazing that people still play this god-awful game. I think the most this game ever was, was an alternative to fortnite for the sake of internet argument. Battle royales have never been good, and will likely never become good- especially if they continue to look like this pile of trash. PubG is one of the stupidest games ever made, I really hate it a lot, and now, I come to find that it is completely free. Of course these developers, and steam, being the slimy dirtbags they are, refuse to give me my $30 back despite the fact that they could have just taken my money and set it on fire and flushed it down the toilet and it would have achieved the same thing. My entire experience with this game is completely tarnished and awful. Anyone who still plays this game should be ashamed of themselves, and the developers of this game should be more than ashamed. This game is terrible, and so is everything it stands for. Fuck. This. Game. Fuck everything about it. Fuck the developers, and fuck steam for allowing this kind of shit on their store. I can't even say I hate the people who play this game really, because I mostly just feel bad for them. I don't know what kind of psychological trauma it takes to be able to endure more than 5 fucking minutes of this game, but I know it must be worse than the worst kind of physical abuse imaginable next to a stabbing, because in order to play this game you must literally have less brain-cells floating around in your head than a rotting turd. I think that jokes aside though, even besides the fact that the devs robbed me blindly, and let their game fall completely to pieces, this game is still really fucking boring. I just think battle royales are the stupidest thing ever. It's probably just me though. I think this game should have always been free. It's never been in a state where it feels like it should cost me more than just the few games I subjected myself to. I don't know how it became popular, but I am glad people aren't being robbed for it anymore at the very least.

From the moment I booted up [Game Title], I knew I was in for a world of pain. This disaster of a game promises excitement but delivers nothing short of a migraine-inducing nightmare.

Graphics:
Let's start with the graphics, or should I say, the abomination that passes for graphics in this game. It's as if the developers hired a blindfolded toddler to smear finger paint across a canvas and called it a day. Characters are rendered with all the detail of a potato, and the environments look like they were ripped straight from a 1990s screensaver.

Gameplay:
If you enjoy frustration and disappointment, then congratulations, you've found your holy grail. The controls are about as responsive as a sloth on sedatives, making even the simplest tasks feel like an exercise in futility. And don't get me started on the camera angles; it's like the game wants you to suffer.

If you enjoy the sweet serenade of nails on a chalkboard, then you might find something to like about the sound design in [Game Title]. From ear-piercing voice acting to repetitive background music that will haunt your dreams, every auditory aspect of this game is a symphony of agony.

Rating:
1 out of 10 - And that's being generous.

PUBG is a survival-shooter BR and it does just that. Understand that there is a learning curve if you're new to the genre or to gaming in general. Key takeaways*

1) There is a certain pay-to-play hidden cost in the game, namely your gaming rig. Without a decent card and setup, you're going to be at a disadvantage versus some 240hz 4090ABCXXXti dude/chick/He/She/Me/Them/Thou in his mom's basement. Its just how shit rolls. If youre offended because I hit one of your 3rd genders, well, fuck you. Sorry, not sorry 

2) The implementation of a deathcam is probably one of the best things (and only things) the game does right, where it lets you see from your killer's POV, and you can then see like "Wow holy fuck that was stupid, why did i run like some braindead zombie out in the field and get hard railed by some sniper". It pretty much allows you to improve and NOT falsely report people for aimbotting etc., that said though, there is a sizable amount of toxic players / cheaters in-game 

3) The game is pretty large, maintaining servers are expensive, i can get behind that. [h1] You land on a mysterious island... and you realize that the only way for you to survive is to participate in the battle royale of death! Good luck. [/h1]

[b] The tension is high in the plane as players are preparing to jump off. Where will YOU go? [/b]

"You only live once! Let's at least try out a weapon before you die!"
Choose hot drop areas... which are rich with items AND enemies!

"I'm a noob!"
Choose a safer, remote area.

"So where are we going?"
Quietly follow your teammates.

[b] You finally jumped off the plane. But... why are there are so many people? [/b]

"Change of plans."
Don't look back and run to another location.

"Just what I wanted."
Loot quickly and arm yourself.

"I'm the Invisible Man."
Run for cover and hide until everyone leaves.

[b] While you're equipping your weapons and protective gear, you hear footsteps on the first floor! What will you do? [/b]

"This is my territory."
Go downstairs and fight.

"Let's stay calm."
Throw a grenade after locating your enemy.

"Please just leave..."
Close the door and hide.

"I'm not ready for this!"
Prepare to flee.

[b] A fight begins! Bullets are flying all over the place and your teammate gets knocked out! What will you do? [/b]

Revive teammate after taking care of the situation.

Revive teammate regardless of the situation.

Your life is more important. Look for ways to survive.

[b] You barely escape the fierce battle but realize that you're too far from the Circle. What will you do? [/b]

A vehicle will solve my problems.
Search for cars, motorcycles, etc.

Not enough time.
Just run for the Circle!

I still have time.
Continue to loot and fight.

[b] You're finally in the Circle but you hear a gunshot nearby! What will you do? [/b]

"Chaaarge!"
Run towards the gunshot!

"I'll pass."
Avoid the gunshot direction.

"Ooh a fight!"
You observe from afar.

[b] It's quiet on the Battlegrounds and you see a Care Package landing approximately 800m away from you! What will you do? [/b]

"Someone might be nearby."
Give up.

"Let's see what happens."
Go for the Care Package.

[b] Oh well. You turn around but you see dead bodies everywhere and someone looting. What will you do? [/b]

"I have a feeling we're not alone."
Run away before it gets too dangerous.

"Killing two birds with one stone."
Shoot at the enemy.

"BEEEP! BANG BANG!"
Run off after honking or shooting at the air.

[b] A 1v1 duel before your chicken dinner! Your enemy's hiding in the smoke from the smoke grenade. What will you do? [/b]

"You scared?!" Bravely fight by shooting and throwing grenades.

"Faster than lightning!" Head for higher land and take advantage.

"So you wanna play?" Go tactical and use your boost/healing items behind cover while watching your enemy.

PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds (PUBG) delivers an adrenaline-fueled experience that keeps players on the edge of their seats from the moment they parachute onto the battleground until the last survivor stands. Released in 2017, PUBG pioneered the battle royale genre, and its impact on the gaming landscape remains undeniable.

One of PUBG's greatest strengths lies in its dynamic and unpredictable gameplay. Each match presents a unique challenge as 100 players are dropped onto a massive map, scavenging for weapons, armor, and supplies while constantly being forced to move closer together by an encroaching circle of death. This ever-shrinking safe zone forces players into intense encounters, fostering a mix of strategic planning and split-second decision-making.

The game's realistic graphics and immersive sound design further heighten the tension, drawing players into the gritty, war-torn landscapes where every rustle of grass or distant gunshot could spell danger. From the sprawling hills of Erangel to the dense jungles of Sanhok, each map offers its own distinct atmosphere and strategic opportunities, ensuring that no two matches feel quite the same.

PUBG's gunplay is challenging and rewarding, requiring players to master recoil control and bullet physics to secure kills. Whether engaging in long-range sniper duels or frantic close-quarters firefights, the game offers a diverse arsenal of weapons and attachments to suit various playstyles.

While PUBG's gameplay is undeniably addictive, it is not without its flaws. The game's performance can be inconsistent, especially on lower-end hardware, leading to occasional lag spikes and optimization issues. Additionally, the learning curve can be steep for newcomers, as mastering the mechanics and strategies requires time and patience.

Despite these drawbacks, PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds remains a seminal title in the battle royale genre, offering a visceral and immersive experience that continues to captivate players around the world. Whether playing solo, with a squad of friends, or competing in esports tournaments, PUBG delivers heart-pounding action and unforgettable moments that keep players coming back for more.

From Promise to Letdown: PUBG's Disappointing Journey

As a player who eagerly jumped into PUBG from the very beginning (2017), I was captivated by its promise of intense battles and exhilarating moments. The thrill of being dropped onto an island, scrounging for weapons, and battling it out against dozens of other players had me hooked from the start.

However, my initial excitement has since turned into disappointment as PUBG has failed to live up to its potential. What was once a promising game filled with endless possibilities has become a shadow of its former self, plagued by a multitude of issues and missed opportunities.

One of the most frustrating aspects of PUBG is its lack of meaningful updates and improvements. Despite numerous promises from the developers, the game has remained stagnant, with fundamental issues such as optimization problems and server issues persisting for years.

Furthermore, the introduction of paid loot boxes and microtransactions has soured the experience, turning what was once a fair and balanced playing field into a pay-to-win nightmare. It's disheartening to see a game that once prided itself on skill and strategy devolve into a cash grab fueled by greed.

To add insult to injury, the constant influx of cosmetic items, particularly those catering to the Asian market, has only served to clutter the game and detract from its immersive atmosphere. Instead of focusing on meaningful gameplay improvements, the developers seem more interested in churning out superficial additions to milk players for more money.

As a longtime fan of PUBG, it pains me to see how far the game has fallen. What started as a promising concept has been squandered by poor management decisions and a lack of commitment to delivering a quality experience. Unless significant changes are made, I can no longer in good conscience recommend PUBG to anyone looking for a satisfying gaming experience.

Welcome to PUBG, where getting shot in the back is a rite of passage and winning feels as unlikely as winning the lottery twice. Get ready for a rollercoaster ride through glitches, chaos, and questionable life choices.

The "Charm" of PUBG:
Ever dreamt of spending half your game hunting for a weapon, only to be taken out by someone named "xXxSn1perXxX"? Welcome to PUBG, where the odds are never in your favor and every bush is a potential death trap.

Glitches: The Feature You Didn't Ask For:
Who needs polished gameplay when you can have a glitchy adventure through walls and floors? PUBG offers a crash course in levitating cars and teleporting players, turning every match into a comedy of errors.

Lost in Translation:
Teamwork makes the dream work, unless your teammate's microphone sounds like a potato in a blender. Cue the incomprehensible shouting as you try to coordinate an attack. Who knew "let's go to the drop zone" could sound so much like "let's go eat a donut"?

Conclusion:
In short, PUBG is the game where chaos reigns and sanity goes to die. But if you're up for a wild ride and don't mind sacrificing your dignity for a few laughs, PUBG might just be your cup of glitchy tea. Just remember to pack your sense of humor—and maybe a stress ball or two. Cheers to the madness, and may your chicken dinners be as elusive as a leprechaun's pot of gold.

this game screams mid. I've played it since release and coming back to it is a semi-yearly ritual. The guns feel good, the recoil is silly but fine, the cheaters are mostly banned. I miss when this game was more survival oriented and less trying to be a fast-paced shooter. The long range fights, the slow game, that was fun. This isn't CoD and nearly every additional map just sucks. Of course, there's no way to pick the maps you want to play, so you're forced into that shitshow that is Sanhok. The monetization is even worse than PUBG Mobile (which is somehow still a more enjoyable experience, still allowing you to choose maps). You win nothing tokens and can collect thousands of them for a chance at a nothing spray or some bullshit like that. It's trying so hard to be an outdated MMOJRPG with the collection of tokens and crafting items and- seriously, what the fuck is this? The game is fine (besides the maps) but feels a little dated; it can be fun but your time is probably better spent elsewhere. I miss the age of good battle royales like Ring of Elysium (in its prime), Fortnite is really the only competent Battle Royale even worth playing at this point. It's such a shame the genre died so painfully. 

I might still play it from time to time, but calling it a guilty pleasure feels like an exaggeration. Go play mobile if you wanna see PUBG Altyn guy fly around with a grappling hook and magical samurai sword.
Came back to this game after some years, it's still thriving. Y'all should give it a try!!!! lmao

The game has some issues with cheaters but there is a decent enough reporting system in place that handles them and hands out bans fairly frequently. The game has seen constant updates which is always necessary for games like this and I think why it retains the player base that it currently has. 
Combat can be fun but frustrating sometimes when in the heat of the moment you suffer damage that may have been different than what you were expecting. There is a variety of maps that I wish were in constant rotation because I feel that a given rotation has a map removed for an entire month and I like to experience all the different places to play at. 
There is a huge amount of different currencies and tokens that can be frustrating to navigate and add complexity to cosmetic crafting that is unnecessary. It can be disheartening to find out you need several hundred dollars worth of currency to upgrade a progressive weapon or have to stick to playing the game for dozens if not hundreds of hours to complete it otherwise. I've never approved systems like this but to each their own.
Overall, I think it's a fun experience, enhanced when you play with people you like instead of random strangers but even that can bring benefits. Partying up is easy enough and lobbies usually never have issues in staying intact. Drop in and get kitted because PUBG is ready for you.

PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds offers a thrilling experience with just the right balance of realism and excitement. From its intense firefights to its strategic gameplay mechanics, every moment feels authentic and immersive. The attention to detail in weapon handling and environmental interactions adds depth to the gameplay, keeping me on the edge of my seat. The vast maps provide endless possibilities for exploration and tactical maneuvers, ensuring each match is a unique adventure. Whether playing solo, with friends, or in intense squad battles, PUBG delivers adrenaline-pumping action that keeps me coming back for more. It's a must-play for fans of realistic battle royale experiences.

2024:

This game sucks ass and has obviously shifted to cater to mobile markets, casual gameplay, and foreign userbases. While these things individually are fine in their own rights, this has resulted in a game that constantly wants you to buy stuff either directly or open a bunch of CSGO-style crates with most rewards having no real value on the Steam market. The maps are too big, encountering another player takes too long, character models can be hard to see especially the farther away they are, the cosmetics are very uninteresting, and the queue time for FPP solos is about 2 minutes. Oh and the TTK is still unbearably small. Getting 2 tapped by an SKS from a guy 300 feet away is ridiculous.

This game was kind of fun when it came out but really only had the advantage of being the only BR out that wasn't fortnite and had a decently sized playerbase. Now it is less fun than fortnite and has no real ambitions except for milking its NA and SEA users for all they can, with a heavy focus on those SEA users.

As a shooter it is great, the problems arise with all the new changes that have never been made as they should be in the last two years. The first problem that my friends and I have are always new and new irrelevant map updates or even more uninteresting new maps made according to the same principle. The only good map in the last 2 years is Deston both in terms of looks and the secret rooms (better weapons and equipment) in it and the use of the drone (but guess what? there were new updates and the drones disappeared and thus made the rooms useless, and on top of that there is still a chance to get deston in a random map for a real 5%, especially with the arrival of Taego 2 (Rondo). All maps are made according to the principles of Korea, China and completely uninteresting (sorry, not all of them, but the ones we have to play, because you get Erangel or Miramar or Deston as rarely as you'll find a flare gun in the game). Not to mention that the maps are unblockable and you have to go out and in and out and in eight times... just to play one normal map that was in this game from beginning. There were also some minimaps, but luckily someone had the sense to remove it and put it to a minimum (they appear every 4-8 months, like some kind of hemorrhoid)

The second problem the most shittiest anticheat there is in 2024 the price would go to PUBG !!! Swarm of cheaters in every game (they get banned but they can make an account in 1 minute and continue to play - it should be that they can only play the game via digital platforms like steam, because here I doubt that anyone will buy a new phone, make new mail and buy new games when they are banned, the fact is that there would be a lot less of them than there are now), if you are unable to make a prober anticheat that is.

Third problem is the ugly cosmetics for the players' weapons and clothes (80% for garbage), considering that it takes you 10 minutes (if you look at some i would say you are competing who can make it faster and uglier) to make some skin for weapons or clothing, you could at least make one that coincides with some other culture than Asian (dragon on dragon on dragon with some ugly bunnies and 10000 diffrent colors...its getting really annoying oooo dont forget asian-fusion (make viking horns put something asian on it - this will sell for sure)


I have nothing against any culture and respect everything, but if you sell something as a global game (try to include something global as well). Or the game will decline, as it has in the last few years.

The only good things in recent years was the collaboration with McLaren and Aston Martin and the new map Deston (without later updates).

I cannot, for the life of me, fathom how PUBG has these "major" updates that seemingly adds a lot of features but change nothing with the core gameplay, stagnating the whole feel of the game. Meanwhile Apex, and other BRs are not afraid to take risks adding, removing, and even reworking their core systems. The current devs of this game cannot even fix old bugs. Always verifying the game after every patch which I find to be odd since this is the only game in my library CONSTANTLY asking me to do so. They also have the gall to heavily monitize this game, adding layers upon layers of currency and RNG making these processes convoluted, meanwhile removing FREE and GOOD rewards a player can work on. I get that APEX has heavily monetized their game with their skins and heirlooms BUT at the very least, a player can work on getting those skins with minimal or even without using money AND they look good.

I am not saying that they have zero good thing added to the game. The sandstorm on miramar or the snowstorm in vikendi, those legacy map reworks, the addition of mortar and redeploy, improved ping system, those are all good additions and enhancement to the game but i feel like they're throwing everything in a wall and seeing what sticks with these patches. New maps aren't even good, the old smaller version maps, I feel, have been forgotten. 

It is sad that the game that started the BR trend has now been trend-chasing. Sadge.

As a player in OCE let me start by stating that this game is by no means perfect. From time to time you may be in a lobby that is really only 3 teams and everyone else is bots, you will get the occasional cheater and compared to other BR games out there the pace of a PUBG match is quite a bit slower. Additionally the removal of Solo FPP is extremely frustrating, especially when they still keep the Team Deathmatch servers up that can never be filled as not enough players play it. 

In saying all of this, I came back to this game after 3 years playing other games and the changes they have made to balancing, Quality of life improvements, new features and even the silly missions has made me genuinely enjoy this game as they seem to really be taking feedback from a larger stand point and look to improve the game with each update. 

When looking at other notable titles such as Fortnite, APEX Legends or the kiddy friendly Farlight, the play-style of PUBG still stands tall. Unlike these other titles, this game has a deeper tactical feel more akin to CS or Siege and if you can get 2 or 3 of your mates to all come together, hours of fun ensues. If you are a 100% solo player, may have more fun on the aforementioned titles above, however if you are looking to play with others, have genuine fun and have a more tactical shooter experience while still knowing this is just casual fun - I would recommend this game over CS2 in a heartbeat.

I would call this the "o.g. battle royale" as this is the one that really set the entire genre off on the right foot. Sadly the graphics and gameplay feel dated at this point so hopefully PUBG2 comes someday. I really enjoy the variety of maps and weapons compared to most other BR's. 


Update: Recent updates are moving this game further away from its core and further towards being a warzone clone, such as the ability to re-spawn teammates. Also, the addition of so much bloat has completely destabilized this game. I used to run on max settings and it looked and ran like a dream on my pc years ago. Now I get lots of lag and de-sync issues making the game literally unplayable at times. Overall I no longer recommend this game and hope someday we either get an optimized pubg2 in unreal5 or a pubg classic that reverts all the bloat to the og game. 
Also beware that cheaters are RAMPANT in this game. I can't tell you how many wall hacks and aim hacks I go up against but it's almost at least 1 player each game, even in casual mode. Their anti-cheat system is very bad despite how much cpu it eats up with its spyware. 

Update 2: To make matters worse the battlepass system was just updated with Rondo to require real money to purchase instead of in-game premium currency that's been used for years (G-coin). This screwed over players who purchased in-game premium currency and saved it for future battlepasses. Very scummy as there's no way to get your money back from previously purchased G-coin. 

Update 3: Add on to update 1 after custom building a new PC (my last one was 8 years old) my performance issues are largely gone. It seems the game has just bloated so much in the last 7 years that my CPU and RAM could no longer handle it. I still think a game that old should be optimized for the hardware it was released on, not for newer hardware. An old game shouldn't require brand new hardware to work.

PUBG has given me some of the best and worst moments of my gaming career.
I paid $30 for it and now they're telling me I can't play it unless I accept new terms stating that I don't own what I paid for. So I can no longer say that I still love this game or what its business model has become. I only love what the game software has become.
I attended the major tournaments that were hosted in California, I have supported this game since the beta. I understand that the legitimate agreement to the "ownership" of any intellectual property is not something granted through any purchase of a game, whether it be a physical or digital release of a game title. But the terms of use now tell us who did pay money for this product that we are effectively rug-pulled and must agree to the terms to play this game again. So I won't be doing so anytime soon.

First started playing during beta, it was a game that once stood as a pinnacle of the battle royale genre. It is sad there’s not any better alternative if you’ve played this. Please never buy this game if you don’t have anything better to do, it is a waste of money and will make you rage.
I think the game is at its all time low - January 2024.

Positive:
- Making kills actually gives an adrenaline rush.
- Winning a game actually feels meaningful.
- Weapon handling is nicely balanced and you can actually get your own style, you’re not forced to play with a certain gun or loadout.

Negative:
- Hard to learn, you’re against people with 1000+ hours that will kill you before you see them.
- Takes a ton of time to learn the maps.
- Maps are rotating and can’t be chosen.
- Be prepared to be killed by sweatlords.
- Be prepared to kill some dumb AI when you expect players.
- Be prepared to get destroyed by cheaters, which you report and get banned for 1 day. and yes they are mostly Chinese and Russian.
- They want you to spend $$ on skins and seasonpasses. Please don’t buy crates to get weapon skins, it is a scam.

[h1]Unleashing the Thrill of Battle:[/h1][h2] PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS[/h2]


[list]
[*]PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS, the groundbreaking battle royale sensation developed by PUBG Corporation, stands as a landmark in the realm of multiplayer gaming, redefining the genre with its heart-pounding gameplay and relentless action. Set against the backdrop of a sprawling island landscape, players are thrust into a high-stakes battle for survival, where only the strongest, smartest, and most skilled will emerge victorious.

[*]At its core, PUBG excels in its ability to deliver an adrenaline-fueled experience that keeps players on the edge of their seats from start to finish. The game's signature blend of intense gunplay, strategic decision-making, and heart-pounding tension creates a dynamic and immersive gameplay experience that is unmatched in its intensity. From the rush of adrenaline as the final circle closes in to the euphoria of securing a hard-fought victory, every match is a rollercoaster ride of emotions and excitement.

[*]Central to the PUBG experience is its emphasis on player choice and emergent gameplay. With a vast array of weapons, vehicles, and equipment at their disposal, players are given the freedom to approach each match in their own unique way, whether it be through stealthy infiltration, aggressive combat, or tactical teamwork. The open-ended nature of the game's sandbox environment encourages creativity and experimentation, inviting players to adapt and innovate in the face of ever-changing challenges.

[*]Moreover, PUBG boasts stunning visuals and immersive sound design that further enhances the player's experience. From the lush landscapes of Erangel to the rugged terrain of Miramar, every aspect of the game's audiovisual presentation is meticulously crafted to draw players deeper into the world of battle royale. The attention to detail is palpable, with the crackle of gunfire and the roar of engines serving to heighten the sense of immersion and intensity.

[*]However, PUBG is not without its flaws and frustrations. The game's steep learning curve and punishing difficulty may prove daunting for newcomers, requiring patience and perseverance to master its mechanics and tactics. The unforgiving nature of its gameplay can lead to moments of frustration and disappointment, as players are often left at the mercy of luck and circumstance in the heat of battle.

[*]Furthermore, PUBG performance and optimization issues may detract from the overall experience, with frequent frame rate drops, server lag, and connection issues disrupting the flow of gameplay. While efforts have been made to address these concerns through updates and patches, they remain persistent challenges that can impact the enjoyment of the game for some players.

[*]In conclusion, PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS stands as a testament to the power of the battle royale genre, offering players a thrilling and immersive experience that pushes the boundaries of multiplayer gaming. With its intense action, strategic depth, and emergent gameplay, PUBG invites players to test their mettle in the ultimate test of skill and survival. While its flaws and frustrations may test the resolve of some players, its adrenaline-fueled excitement and heart-pounding intensity make it a journey well worth undertaking. As players parachute into the battlegrounds, they are reminded that in the chaos of battle, victory belongs to those bold enough to seize it.
[/list]

250hrs in and still loving it (love/hate relationship).

Personally, solo is fun, but duo and squads are much more enjoyable. Version 1.0 has it's issues, but the huge improvements (vaulting, fps,lag,disconnects, ..) and the fun factors out-weigh these issues for me.

250 hours and I can confirm 2 or 3 hackers (speed/aim) and have had just as few questionables.  After reading these reviews it seems like others have hackers every game (or people they acuse of it because they get shot).  

Pros:
- Adrenaline rush!
- Co-op with friends
- Excellent graphics and frame rate after version 1.0 released (GTX 1060 6GB)
- Tasty chicken

Cons:
- Some hackers for me, 99% matches good (NA server 6pm-12pm EST mostly)
- Harassment with in-game voice leads to usually muting
-    Everyone seems to want me to f**k my mother in the lobby chat
-    Many times dieing in-game leads to a non-instigated verbal putdown
-    Most of the playerbase is fun, but there seems to be a 20% a-hole ratio

Play the game for fun and you won't be dissapointed.

Here's my honest take for this game as for now

PROS:

+4 big maps
+Weapon mods with combinations
+Frequent updates and rebranding to make it fresh and new
+It CAN be fun gameplay. Not gonna lie the game is very fun once you learned the basics.
CONS:

-The game just wont boot up sometimes and will whenever it feels like it
-Uses Battleye 
-Bullshit fucking hit detection. I held a fuckign crowbar and SOMEHOW I couldn't land a hit on the enemy yet he fully killed me with his bare hands.
-Servers are too busy errors
-Crashes
-Soundtracks are terrible
-Crates within lootboxes
-Long a s s loading times. It's so long that the game loaded the whole thing and it's running but I'm stuck in the loading screen for a few minutes before I get dropped out of the plane.
-Hats are too large to fit the character's head
-Cheaters
-Crap outfit design. Do you ever wonder why Fortnite is a very success game? Because skins. Players can pay like 10 dollars to get their battle pass, and get skins along the way by doing challenges, plus some rewards even have in-game currency. That's amazing. This trash, however doesn't. Hell, even H1Z1 gives out free lootboxes and free cool clothes, unlike this trash. Hell, if you want to change your player's[strike] face, hair[/strike]  (now it free) gender you'll need to pay in-game currency and it's about... probably 2 days of full game time to have enough. How pathetic is that? 
Maps are way too large. For maps this huge I think it's about 250 PLAYERS to be enough to fit in these maps. It just takes forever to walk from one point to another I think they should add more vehicles.
-Bad, cheap a s s engine.
-No offline mode / bot mode
-Clunky gameplay. The first person and third person view felt unnatural and can get unpredictable at times when you're in close corners.
-So much uneccesary loading times like waiting a full minute before starting match when 100 people are joined like WTF were they thinking?
-Lack of features that other leading BR games use such as NEXT MATCH upon death
-Lifeless environments and lack of nature sounds
-Poor optimization
-Lack of MSAA setting
-Being hit by an enemy from afar is next to impossible to know which direction the bullet was fired from. In games like COD you will see traces of bullets fired however in this game it is impossible. You'll have to drive around like an idiot and possibly get shot to know where the enemy is hiding in and shooting from. 
-Extremely quiet sounds. The enemy sounds in this game like footsteps is so impossibly quiet to hear that I can't wrap it around my head how is this good idea for a game like this.

3/10

Kind of boring and empty Battle Royale game, in my opinion.

PUBG was the first Battle Royale game I played, when the genre was still new for me. I liked its style of playing, with the arena that got smaller over time, finding weapons to defend yourself against other players and the teamwork when playing with friends. 

My fun however, was short-lived with this game. This was mainly because I thought it looks and feels a little empty. I played many times with friends, and even then, I got this feeling. Normally when I play any game with friends, this is not the case, so for me, I knew that this was not a game that I would play for many years.

The graphics in PUBG are a little boring. I did not expect shiny next generation visuals or something, but everything is almost the same color, green grasslands with a orange sky. It looks kind of realistic, like everyday life, but the whole atmosphere just felt hollow. The sound effects from weapons are great and get close to realism.

The controls and movement are a little stiff and felt a little slow. This is mainly because of the big world you are walking in, making a mile really feel like a mile. 

My problem, as always, with this kind of games, is that I am just not skilled enough. I try very hard to stay alive and kill another player, but they are always faster than me. Well, in a game like Counter Strike for example, this is fine, I respawn immediately and can try again and might get some kills and streaks afterwards. But with games like PUBG, you walk around, collect stuff, do not see a living soul in sight and then *Bam*, dead. For me, the game is over and I need to find another server to play on. 

Then you got the fact that this game felt like Battlefield 2, my arch nemesis when talking online shooters. Massive open, empty world, walk for miles and miles, and then get shot. It was some sort of Vietnam flashback for me and I immediately disliked the game by the second.

The biggest problem, that has been patched if I am not mistaken, was that players could turn down their graphics to potato mode, in which grass and foliage disappeared. This gave them a huge advantage over players that were hiding in the grass to avoid being killed. For me, this almost killed all the fun I had with the game at the time. 

In the end, PUBG was fun for a couple of hours, and I had some joy with it, but with the knowledge of today, I prefer Apex Legends over this one anytime.

For me personally, I would not recommend this game.

Still the best realistic FPS battle royale game. The game is still fairly well supported with new maps, guns, vehicles etc. being consistently added to the game. If another realistic BR game was released to compete with PUBG, I'd consider it, but I think the next step will be PUBG converting to Unreal Engine 5 and updating the graphics.

Many other battle royale games are goofy and less tactical in that you end up spamming movement, building etc just to be evasive. PUBG has leaning, recoil, bullet velocity and drop, attachments etc.  All of which feel really good for gun play mechanics. This is essentially the cs player's BR game.

This game is meant to be played in First Person Perspective (FPP) and in a Squad. The problem with Third Person Perspective (TPP) is that you don't have to expose your character to peak around a corner and dying to somebody that is abusing this mechanic feels really bad. Everybody is entitled to play what they enjoy, but the vast majority of players prefer FPP. If you're new, playing solo is going to feel bad as you have nobody to teach you or help you when you're facing sweaty veteran players. Try to find players to squad up with by queuing into squads and playing with your team. Then join the players that you enjoyed squading with if they're willing to add you. Practice your recoil control in practice mode and team death match to get better. If you only ever play normal BR mode, you only get a few opportunities to fight a player who is better than you before being sent back to the lobby. Team Death Match fixes that and gives you attempt after attempt to learn to play against more experienced players. Pay close attention to sound cues from footsteps or gunfire as this is critical to being able to react quickly. It's a bit of an uphill climb for new players but if you've played other shooters you should be alright if you stick with it.

I've found that as the game has matured, the community has gotten a lot more close knit and friendly which is actually nice. I seldom am stuck playing alone at this point. There are plenty of times where I can recognize players in the kill feed and know what I'm up against.

People complain constantly about cheaters, but in most cases, if you're really being honest with yourself and watch your deathcam, the player that killed you was just better. Every now and then I die to players that are suspect but it's actually fairly rare. Most of the time, you're dying to somebody with thousands of hours on the game (since this game is nearly 7 years old) who CAN actually turn on a dime and double headshot you from 100 meters away. I know this may seem ridiculous but if you watch pro players, you'll see that it is actually possible. Sometimes I surprise myself with the shots that I hit as one of those players. Actual cheaters are banned on a weekly basis, and it does seem like the developers are doing what they can to combat cheating. The fact that the game is free to play is always going to present a problem though where anybody that is determined enough to cheat will simply create a new account to cheat on when their current account gets banned.

All in all, there isn't a game out there that provides the same level of strategy and tension that you get from PUBG, and I look forward to Unreal Engine 5 giving the game a much needed graphics overhaul.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

It's true that it's best times are behind it. Bought copy when it was released, got busy, only to find out later that it's been made free (WTF???). Now, hacking is obviously prevalent. I play casually for the challenge. Killing someone who is obviously cheating is a reward I settle for. Forget actually winning a game - those times are gone as there are too many people cheating and the anti-cheat system is very weak. With Krafton sacking employees currently due to the global economic climate and general greed, it ensures that things regarding cheating will not improve over time. To Krafton: Regular rounds of banning accounts permanently of proven cheaters/hackers would be a start.

EDIT: Krafton suspends accounts but not ban. I suspect some devs earning some side hustle selling cheats/"services" otherwise any known form of cheating would be patched by now but I guess there's more money to be had this way, right? Really-poor effort. Players will respond kindly with their wallets and game time.

EDIT: So you spend time queuing for a match with delays on the intro, people only get to live once - no respawn, the world gets smaller, and people playing as if it's Counter Strike? ****Ye still love it, i find myself coming back to pubg here and there, playing a few months then taking a few months rest. Its fun, some cheaters here and there, but honestly... i'll see one a month if that. The posts screaming about hackers and cheaters are cry babies that are probably just terrible at the game. So don't let that stop you jumping in and having some fun. It'll take a while to get used to the somewhat heavy movement feel, gun play and attachment management ...but its easy enough to google what attachments work best for what ever weapons you find yourself enjoying. Updates are regular and they keep trying new things here and there with promotional events and such things to keep your interest peaked.There are a few annoyances but on top of that there's a lot of fun to be had. Where else could i beat to death a crying kid on open mic with a frying pan and at the same time have one of my randomly assigned  team mates squeal like a pig down his mic as i get the kill. The community is a good laugh and i regularly find myself loling hard at the comments and characters that reveal themselves on the open mic feature. 
Jump in, have a laugh, shoot some plebs, then get told your mums an ape by a 12 year old on open mic. its a blast.****


Original review:

After a couple weeks play i can safely say this games a pretty good waste of your time :D reading a lot of reviews some good some bad, i decided to give it a go anyway... and i found it to be real good fun.
I've played a number of different royal games over the last year and this one comes top of my list.
I've come across no cheaters in games, nothing game stopping at all. Its good fun solo and great fun in squads.
If you like shooters which require you to gear up then go on the hunt whilst being sneaky and being tactical minded you will love this game.
Plenty of depth, which will take a good few hours to get used to and master.... but once you do it all feels like second nature and you'll be head shotting unsuspected players in no time.
I think most of the negetivity for this game came from the earlier days when cheaters were rampant and region locking wasnt a thing (China no:1).  Now thats all been sorted out i would say give it a go.
Its still one of the top played games on steam and servers are always full no matter what time of day or night it is.
Still a great play and well worth the price.

I have owned this game since its launch and feel it is now unplayable. A game that once stood as a pinnacle of the battle royale genre, now finds itself shackled by an insurmountable problem: an epidemic of cheaters that has left the gaming experience in shambles. As an avid supporter of the game, it's disheartening to witness the degradation of fair play at the hands of those who exploit and manipulate PUBG's mechanics with blatant disregard for the principles of integrity. The issue of cheating has reached such alarming proportions that it feels as if PUBG Corporation has relinquished control of its own creation, allowing an unchecked proliferation of aimbots and wall hacks to run rampant.

Despite promises of improved anti-cheat measures, the reality on the ground paints a different picture. PUBG's feeble attempts to curb cheating have proven ineffective, leaving players to navigate a virtual battlefield marred by the constant threat of encountering dishonest players. The once-thrilling engagements that defined PUBG's appeal are now overshadowed by the fear that each firefight may be tainted by the presence of a cheater, eroding the trust and enjoyment of the player community.

It's 2021 and there are still hackers in this game. Reporting does nothing, its more mindless and fun to shoot bots than even attempting to shoot the hackers.

It's 2022, still hackers in this game with their walling and recoil hacks, its interesting to come back once in awhile to see what updates there are, ranging from new maps to new utilities/weapons and even a mountain bike to go with your reenactment as a Japanese solider invading South East Asia. Once again reporting cheaters does nothing and its still as fun as watching undergarments dry.

it's 2023, Tactical gear came and gone, Battlepasses came and gone, Wackyjacky skins came and gone, there is a new map on the horizon, there were several events that were hit and miss, a new DMR and multiple sets of new cosmetics. But the core issue still run rampant and the issue is cheaters, while the reporting system has seem some use, it still doesn't permanently solves the issue even in the ranked levels. At this point of the game, lets see what else can the developers do to address this issue.

Lets see what 2024 brings

Honestly has really picked up lately, the developers are putting a lot more work into it and it is really showing in a positive way, they are releasing new maps, guns, vechiles pretty regularly and with each map addition the game feels more diverse as it goes with different play areas and styles for each scenario.

The game also gives out a lot of free rewards through log-in events and other seasonal events that appear almost every week/month that provide a rewarding feeling for playing and logging in which keeps the player base alive, a feature a lot of other games could do with.

It also usually has a good battle pass with A LOT of rewards in in it where you don't feel bad for buying it, given that it also gives G-COIN at the end of it usually I think also helps.

Honestly a solid game, with solid rewarding game play and a rather generous distribution of items, which is only a good thing as it makes you want to play the game even more.

life were a PUBG match, I'd probably be that person hiding in a bathtub, clutching a frying pan, and wondering why parachuting out of a plane became a recreational activity. But hey, that's the charm of PUBG – where the chicken dinners are as elusive as my sense of direction.

Let's talk about the graphics. PUBG's landscapes are so breathtakingly realistic that I often find myself admiring the scenery while an enemy sniper admires the back of my head. The attention to detail is so precise that you can almost smell the virtual grass as you desperately crawl toward cover, hoping the enemy misses their shots.

Now, the looting system – it's like a virtual Black Friday, except instead of discounted TVs, you're fighting for the last energy drink like it's the elixir of life. I spend more time scavenging for bandages than I do in my actual kitchen looking for snacks. And don't get me started on the constant struggle to find a decent pair of pants – fashion in PUBG is truly a life-or-death decision.

The map is massive, and if there's one thing PUBG has taught me, it's that I'm geographically challenged. I can't count the number of times I've sprinted towards what I thought was the safe zone, only to realize I'm headed straight into a war zone. My character's cardio is on point, but my map-reading skills are about as reliable as a chocolate teapot.

Let's address the sound effects – the footsteps, the gunfire, the distant explosions – it's like an immersive ASMR experience, only with added adrenaline and the occasional expletive when you realize someone's camping in the bathroom you just walked into.

In summary, PUBG is a rollercoaster of emotions – from the thrill of parachuting into battle to the agony of being eliminated by someone with a username like "NoobSlayer9000." It's a game where strategy meets chaos, and your survival depends on your ability to find a decent helmet and not panic when the circle starts closing in. Would I recommend it? Absolutely. Just be prepared to question your life choices as you sprint across an open field with nothing but a frying pan for protection.

And let's not forget about PUBG's newest Rondo map with markets – because nothing says intense battle royale like haggling for supplies while avoiding sniper fire.

The markets in Rondo are like the chaotic bazaars of the virtual world. I spend more time bargaining with virtual vendors for ammo than I do negotiating my salary in real life. I can almost hear my character yelling, "Can I get a discount on these painkillers? I'm a loyal customer!"

{TL;DR} Buggy game with a bad dev team that is over run by cheating Chinese players on every server because the devs wont add a ping limiter to lock them to the Asian servers.

Seeing as how my last review was a bit outdated, I’m going to update this. I would still like to point out that I wrote this review back around the time when the game first came out and it was still at like a 80% positive score because I knew this would happen. And everyone who left a comment back then... well they didn't age well. Now… For the sake of organization and so this doesn’t turn into a book, I’m going to split all the problems into categories. 

[b]Gameplay[/b] : The whole premise of this game is you fly into the map on a plane and you jump out with 100 other players and try to survive. The first problem comes with this game’s engine. It cannot support 100 players on the same map at the same time. It can only support around 75 or so. Meaning for the first section of the game, you will be lagging. Any items you try to pick up you will have to pick up at least 10 times before it goes into your inventory. Also the beginning of the game is awful. It is basically people running around to find a gun, and if you don’t find one fast enough then the enemy will find one and kill you instantly. Players lag and even if you shoot them it wont register a hit because of ping. The game runs awful. Only beefy computers can run this game, even though it isn’t impressive graphics wise, because it is unoptimized and coded awfully. On top of this most people turn off a lot of the settings like foliage or shadows and so on so they can see players from farther away. So they are just useless settings in the end hindering the games performance unless forced to be used or removed. Also a lot of the game is just camping and being prone so no one sees you as you  shoot people from far away. That is what 80% of all your deaths are going to be after you get past the unfair beginning section of trying to find a gun. 

[b]Community[/b] : Due to the dev teams refusal to add a ping limiter every server has a ton of Chinese people. This leads to joining a US server, hearing people screaming “China numba whon” a bunch, and half the players on the US server lagging or being unkillable because of their bad ping. They are purposefully joining US servers because they know this. This game is also over run by Chinese hackers, which Playerunkown said himself that most of the cheaters are coming China.
Just look at this screenshot from the steam discussion forum. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1169782535] >LINK<[/url]
You may think that is the Chinese language tab in the discussions page. Nope. That is general discussions on a daily basis. It’s filled with Chinese spam.

[b]Dev Team[/b] : Unprofessional. Back around the time the game first came out, people raised issues about the Chinese people joining the american servers, being hard to kill due to poor ping, and being obnoxious by screaming slurs or using aimbots to Playerunkown. People requested the addition of a ping limiter. Unknown's response was to call these people racists. Since then they have made special censored versions of this game for China and this game's playerbase is made up of over 60% chinese people. The reason why this is a problem is the dev team admitted that over 90% of the hackers are coming from China. The dev team also said they would not add loot boxes until they left Early Access but added them early anyways. Because why not, they could use more money even though their game is a top selling game all the time. The stuff in the loot boxes aren’t even that good tbh. Who cares about a yellow shirt when your being shot, it just makes you easier to see and get sniped. The dev team also threatened to sue Fortnite for making a better Battle Royal game than they did. Because the developers are delusional and believe they created and own the Battle Royal genre, they went ahead and sued Fortnite in a Korean court of law along with some smaller Battle Royal games. They are mad that their game isn't the most popular game ever, because they are greedy and lazy about fixing problems. On top of that, technically PUBG was actually a stolen formula taken from H1Z1. So they are just being hypocrites. The dev team goes as far as to ban people who honk car horns at streamers because “we need to appeal to the people marketing our game”. Also, the fact that you can team-kill in the game and get banned for it is ridiculous. If they don’t like people team-killing, maybe they should disable it instead of banning people and stealing their money for doing it. These devs are so incompetent that they let their source code leak and now there are tons of mobile PUBG rip off games in China that uses their code and actually run better than PUBG somehow. 

[b]Verdict[/b] : If you crave this kind of gameplay, go play Fortnite or CoD or any number of the battle royale clones that greedy companies made to capitalize on the trend.

I've played for 6 years. Over all the game is great and is a lot of fun, especially if you're playing with friends. Weather you like to play by yourself or with a team this is probably for you. Survival isn't about killing everything either. You can go that route or watch everyone off themselves. Favorite era was by far before they officially released the game but all good things come to an end.

PUBG is that first love. 
It was so new and fresh in the beginning. There was nothing else like it. You and your friends had fun for hours and hours. Laughing hysterically at crazy vehicle mechanics. Bitching about rats, sweats, red zones and unlucky circles. As the honeymoon phase wore off you started to notice their little issues. They started to annoy you more and more. Eventually it got so bad you gave up on them for good. Had a huge fight and went your separate ways. Good riddance. You thought your life was better. You dated Apex for a while but that spark wasn’t there. You fooled around with Warzone and something was just missing. Hell you even got into a long term relationship with Tarkov. But the entire time you were comparing them to PUBG. You heard they went free to play. Wow desperate much? Was that just a ploy to get your attention? Were they thinking about you this whole time too? Well the rats in EFT have gotten so bad it’s unplayable… Should we.. give this another try? Wow okay the performance is actually improved, looks like they learned a thing or two while they were discovering theirselves. Damn theres still seemingly random crashes every %$@&ing day, but you know what, you’re home. This is where you were meant to be. Even with its little quirks, how its evolved over time, nothing compares to you. 


TLDR: still has quirks but I keep coming back, nothing as a total package can top this BR

PUBG is the most realistic presentation of "virtual" combat EVER rendered digitally by humans as of today... the only thing more real is that T Cruise deepfake... but as far as all out mayhem and warfare, PUBG takes the cake. It is on another level though, as the developers have gone through insane trials and tribulations to record some of the most captivating audio, which actually allows the better gamers to play with their ears more than their eyes... so def need some good over the ear, anc headsets... and welcome to the real world where shooting anything is difficult at 25 yards, so you better believe you will not be landing much on a running opponent at any considerable distance, so I highly suggest you actually spend time at the shooting range to hone in the surreal bullet physics depicted in this game... many people ask me about PUBG, and I explain it like this.... it's not fun... it's not a quick, easy, enjoyable time... it's gut wrenching, heart racing, anxiety and headaches most of the time for me... but it is that way, because it is not easy... and for that, there kind of is no other shooter out there, where you are forced to get you ish together with your squad, communicate plainly, visualize / vocalize, stay in cover, stay together, have an overall gameplan, and keep your mouth shut if its not necessary, or you will get picked apart... the other factor is, the TIME... its an investment... 20+ minutes sometimes without conflict, looting and prepping and BOOM, its over in a crack of 7.62 to the skull... my time is money, as I'm sure yours is, so that can really start to burn if your not taking the game seriously... let alone piss your teammates off as you dying leaves them down a man... so stay frosty. cim0relli on twitch and steam aka Brian "Azrael" Cimorelli....hit me if youd like to network and get into a lobby... see you on the kill feed...  and again, HUGE PROPS to the PUBG devs and Krafton crew...

这款游戏实在是令人发指，我实在无法忍受PUBG的种种问题而不发牢骚。首先，游戏的优化简直令人生气，无论我使用何种配置，都无法摆脱那肆意妄为的卡顿和崩溃。

游戏中的服务器更是如同破旧的房屋，时常抛弃我们在游戏的关键时刻。网络延迟和掉线问题简直让人抓狂，完全毁了游戏体验。

再者，游戏内的外挂问题更是让人难以容忍。作弊者肆意横行，毫无约束，使得正常玩家的辛勤努力变得毫无意义。这简直是对我们这些付费玩家的嘲弄。

总的来说，PUBG已经让我彻底崩溃。这款游戏的问题堆积如山，简直令人发指。唯一的建议是，如果你想要保持理智，请远离这个游戏。

I've played this game for a few years now since launch, and I think I'm pretty damn good. Excellent at sniping, and can mow down a whole 4 man w/ the AK or Beryl at full auto. It's the most realistic shooter and have wall grabbing now. I play Solo or Duo 4 man Squad, as in I'm always solo or in a duo against 4 man squads. My KDR 1.63 in the last 6 months, and 1.45 over all. 

I just got 1 shotted with 100%HP and a 100% HP lvl 3 helmet by an M24 when I can't even down someone with an M24 when they have a lvl 2 helmet. The amount of client side lag, hacks and bullshit luck that allows worse players to beat me in this game is infuriating and I have dealt with it for 3 years but that 1 shot lvl 3 helmet was the last straw. 

This game, I always feel like I have the drop to just destroy a whole team, but the shitty controls are getting in the way. Shooting window sills, shooting ledges, shooting ceilings, accidentally vaulting off a 6 story (i have vault separately bound for years now.) dumb physics just bumping you the right way to just fall off something. I'm always just battling the fucking game when if it was another engine I'd have taken everyone out. Pretty frustrating. 

I am just over playing 20 matches to have 1 good one where I'm lucky enough to not have the lag/engine/physics/controls fuck me out of winning. I can't play that many games to ACTUALLY play a REAL game of PUBG. It's a waste of my god damn time.

There are still a lot of hackers who toggle, and there is still so much client side lag you will get shot in the past or behind walls constantly or get downed by one shot when the lag allowed for multiple? I've died instantly with full Lvl 3 armor from weak ass guns instantly that I just can't play this shit anymore. Over it.

"PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds (PUBG)" isn't just a game; it's the title that defined and popularized the battle royale genre. With its blend of intense survival gameplay, strategic depth, and unpredictable encounters, PUBG offers a gaming experience that remains unmatched. Here's why PUBG still reigns as a top choice for battle royale enthusiasts:

Intense and Immersive Gameplay: PUBG offers a perfect balance of tension and excitement. The thrill of parachuting onto an island with nothing but the goal to survive and be the last one standing is exhilarating. Every match feels like a new adventure, with varied strategies and playstyles leading to different outcomes.

Realistic and Strategic Combat: The game's realistic gunplay and mechanics set it apart from other battle royales. The need for precise aim, recoil control, and tactical movement makes each engagement a heart-pounding experience. Players must think on their feet, utilizing the terrain and their surroundings to gain an advantage.

Diverse Maps and Environments: PUBG features a variety of maps, each with its unique geography and challenges. Whether it's the dense forests of Erangel, the harsh deserts of Miramar, or the urban sprawl of Sanhok, each map requires players to adapt their strategies to survive.

Regular Updates and Improvements: The developers have consistently updated PUBG, adding new content, refining gameplay, and improving performance. These updates have kept the game fresh and engaging, addressing community feedback and introducing new elements to enhance the player experience.

Strong Community and Competitive Scene: PUBG has a robust and passionate community. The game's competitive scene, including tournaments and events, adds an extra layer of excitement, showcasing the high skill ceiling and strategic depth of PUBG.

Verdict: "PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds" is more than just the game that started the battle royale craze; it's a testament to immersive, strategic gameplay. Its realistic combat, diverse environments, and constant evolution make it a standout title in the genre. Whether you're playing for fun or competing for the top spot, PUBG offers a challenging and rewarding experience that keeps players coming back for more.

Playtime: 3088 hours
Purchased: Dec 28, 2018
★☆☆☆☆ - Deeply Disappointing After Years of Commitment
As a long-time player of PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS, with over 3000 hours invested since late 2018, it's with a heavy heart and deep frustration that I write this review.
My journey with this game has been a rollercoaster. The early days were filled with excitement, challenges, and a community that brought endless hours of enjoyment. However, recent experiences have completely overshadowed these fond memories.
The primary issue began with the game's anti-cheat system. Despite my commitment and fair play, the system repeatedly failed to load on my PC. This technical glitch led to a message stating, "Your game will be shut down in 10 seconds. Verify your PUBG game integrity from Steam." Following all the suggested steps, including verifying game files and restarting my PC, I hoped for a resolution.
But then, the final straw: a sudden and shocking 72-hour ban. There are no explanations, no support, just a blunt and unjustified punishment for an issue that seems entirely on their end. This isn't an isolated incident but a recurring problem that has destroyed the fun and fairness of the game.
Contacting the support team yielded no real help, only adding to the frustration. It feels like a slap in the face to a loyal player. Spending thousands of hours in a game world should build a relationship of trust and respect, but this has been completely eroded.
It's heartbreaking to say, but PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS is no longer the game I fell in love with. What used to be an escape into a thrilling world has turned into a source of annoyance and disappointment. To anyone considering this game, please be wary. The game has its highs, but when the lows hit, they hit hard, especially when your commitment is met with unjust bans and unhelpful support.

It is very fun and thrilling game, I like it very much. I suck at it, die a lot, on a rare occasion get to top 10, and yet still come back to it, because it is just fun.

But, at this point, I cannot recommend it, first of all because of how poorly it is optimized.

I have to turn almost everything in graphics settings to low or very low for the game to be playable. My current hardware is pretty decent (6-core CPU, 16Gb RAM, Radeon R9 R380), and, while it is a little bit old indeed, it handles Witcher 3 on Ultra good enough. Yet apparently it's barely enough for PUBG. Here are the *minimum* system requirements that are stated right now on store page: "Intel Core i3-4340 / AMD FX-6300, 6 GB RAM, nVidia GeForce GTX 660 2GB / AMD Radeon HD 7850 2GB".

I have to say that, to me personally, it feels more optimized after 1.0 release, so maybe it will get better over time.

I hope I will be able to change review to positive one after there will be more optimisations done, or when I'll give gaming PC a significant hardware upgrade. :)

Update 04-2021: still cannot recommend it, it's still not optimised. Two significant hardware upgrades later it still requires a lot of tweaks to run on decent framerate.

Update 01-2024: same :(

Back in the good old days when PUBG had a price tag, we had a special kind of bonding with the cheaters—it was like a paid partnership, you know? Now they've gone all generous and made it free, and voila, the cheater population has skyrocketed. Did they think going free would summon the fair-play fairy or something?

Oh, PUBG, you used to be the blockbuster of gaming. Jumping into matches with friends felt like being part of an epic action movie. Now it's more like stumbling into a comedy horror flick, where the joke's on us, and the horror is the state of the game.

What a wild ride it used to be, PUBG. It's like they traded the magic carpet for a broomstick. Here's to the good times we had, and a moment of silence for what could've been. What a shame, what a freaking shame.

When the term Battle Royale is mentioned, the game PUBG must not be omitted, as it played a crucial role in the inception of this gaming genre. In comparison to other Battle Royale games, PUBG stands out for its realism, whether in terms of the environment, weapons, or overall game physics. The game relies more on tactics and caution, requiring players to watch every corner and stay vigilant at all times. Currently, all of this has been overshadowed by the new and sophisticated Warzone; however, for its loyal players, myself included, PUBG still holds its charm, and I always enjoy returning to it. Weaker computers may struggle with the gameplay, but it's manageable. One aspect that bothers me the most about the gameplay is the slowness and lack of dynamism in the game. However, as I've already mentioned, the game is designed for a realistic battlefield experience, so it's something to be expected.

Back when PUBG first dropped in 2017, it was the hot thing. Fast forward, and the player base has taken a nosedive. The game's dealing with a bunch of issues – cheaters everywhere, weapons that feel off, and gameplay that's just not cutting it anymore. Even big-shot streamers like Shroud and DrDisrespect bailed on PUBG streaming because it's just not pulling in the crowds like it used to.

What's really grinding gears is how the devs seem to care more about pumping out skins for a game that feels like it's on life support. Core issues with the gameplay? They're not getting the attention they deserve. The lack of a solid anti-cheat system is like an open invitation for cheaters to ruin the fun for those of us who used to dig PUBG.

It's a bummer seeing the focus on making money from skins instead of fixing what's broken. If you're thinking of dropping some cash on a game, you might want to look elsewhere. PUBG's in a bit of a sorry state right now, and there are plenty of other games out there offering a better time.

The game itself is fun, as you can see from my hours played. The anti-cheat system, however, is taken way too seriously. I have been temporarily banned 4 times in a month even though I'm 100% sure I haven't violated any terms of service. This is not an isolated case, I have found countless other cases of people in the exact same spot. Even people that have been wrongfully permabanned only to get unbanned after months when PUBG inevitably realizes their mistakes.

The support you get always comes down to 'we can't help you due to security reasons'. 

Also, they install software on your computer that monitors it 24/7, even when you're not playing pubg. If they detect you using a random software such as Unity, they'll flag you, even if you're not using that software whilst playing the game.

Update: Game has seen significant improvement. Despite people trying to say the game is dead it is alive and well. Hackers are actually nowhere near as prevalent as they were in EA. TKers, griefers, AFKers actually do get banned when reported and if you want it to happen within an hour you can submit video evidence to support and they actually ban them. Their support is actually amazing as I even reported an alternate account they logged in with and flagged the account for manual review. The alternate account they logged into was also banned because they started to TK on it as well. Support actually does their job and does it very well. You can get A LOT of cosmetics for free without even paying just by playing the game consistently. Honestly this is by far the most generous battle royale game as far as giving away cosmetics. I have spent less than $10 on this game yet I have over $100 worth of cosmetics just from free BP and G-coin that the game rewards with less than 300 hours in.

Surprisingly the game has improved, it is still the same PUBG at its core but the amount of hackers has died down significantly. This could be due to the lower playercount as the game is past its golden age, but the game is actually pretty enjoyable now.

There are a lot of free items you get if you grind out time in the game to unlock them during their event window. I'm actually surprised that the game has turned it around decently well. Definitely worth a try again.

A LOT of negative reviews are old and even more are from players that get clapped and cry hacks. The hacking problem has significantly gotten better from when I last played.

I don't recommend.  There are far too many cheats available and loads of teamkillers in team matches.  Wait and see if it ever gets cleaned up before spending $30.

I'm changing my review after a few years of negattive one.

As for the 29.12.2023 PUBG is in it's best state when it comes to content/bugs/cheaters, and I've been playing this game with breaks ever since it was released(2017).

What's worth mentioning - I'm speaking about the experience of EU FPP player.
NA/OCE has WAY worse experience due to longer queue times, some modes being close to non existing due to lack of playerbase etc.

I highly recommend this game under one of two conditions:
1. You like playing solo
2. You have people to play duo/squads with

Otherwise - I wouldn't play it at all.

The game really shines If you have a full squad of people to play with.

There are cheaters(thanks to f2p model...), but they're constantly being banned.
It's way better than in early/late 2022 or early 2023.

Rondo is an amazing map and it's early roadmap(till February 2024) looks really promising.

I wish the Devs would also listen to EU/NA community and their feedback, not only Asian. I personally wish the game would have more 'camo like' type of skins rather than a bear/panda/toy/pink madmanlike skins. 
Tho, I can't really complain as I have a huge amount of skins, lol.

Playerbase is pretty loyal, full of veterans that know what they do so newbies will most likely get wiped pretty fast, but well... the game is just enjoyable and offers emotions no other game has.
